title: Preparation for Conquest
shortSummary: Joshua chapter 5 records the spiritual and physical preparation of Israel as they enter the Promised Land. It highlights the renewal of the covenant through circumcision, the celebration of Passover, the cessation of manna, and Joshua's encounter with the commander of the LORD’s army, emphasizing God's presence and holiness.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Israel's entrance into the Promised Land after 40 years in the wilderness

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who commands the people, oversees their circumcision, and encounters the captain of the LORD’s host.

keyCharacters.name: The Captain of the LORD’s Host
keyCharacters.description: A divine messenger who appears to Joshua as commander of the LORD’s army, signifying God's presence and authority.

definitions.definition: A physical sign of the covenant between God and Israel, involving the removal of the foreskin as a mark of belonging to God.
A commemorative feast remembering Israel’s deliverance from Egypt, symbolizing redemption and God's saving power.
The miraculous bread-like substance God provided to the Israelites in the wilderness for sustenance.
The campsite east of Jericho where Israel renewed their covenant and prepared for conquest; the name means 'rolling away' of reproach.

outline.heading: Fear of the Amorite and Canaanite Kings
outline.description: The kings of the land hear of Israel’s miraculous crossing of the Jordan, causing their hearts to melt in fear, demonstrating God’s power before the conquest.

outline.heading: Renewal of the Covenant through Circumcision
outline.description: God commands Joshua to circumcise the new generation born in the wilderness, restoring the covenant sign and removing the reproach of Egypt from Israel.

outline.heading: Celebration of Passover and Cessation of Manna
outline.description: Israel observes Passover in the Promised Land for the first time, eats the produce of the land, and the manna ceases, symbolizing a new season of God’s provision.

outline.heading: Joshua’s Encounter with the Captain of the LORD’s Host
outline.description: Joshua meets a divine warrior who identifies himself as commander of the LORD’s army, instructing Joshua to remove his sandals because the ground is holy, affirming God’s presence and authority.

application: Renew your commitment to God regularly, remembering that spiritual preparation is essential before facing new challenges.
Trust in God’s provision and timing, as He transitions His people from dependence on miracles to enjoying His blessings in the Promised Land.
Recognize and honor the holiness of God’s presence in your life, approaching Him with reverence and obedience.
Celebrate God’s faithfulness through worship and remembrance, just as Israel observed Passover before entering the land.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Joshua, This day have I rolled away the reproach of Egypt from off you. Wherefore the name of the place is called Gilgal unto this day.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the spiritual renewal of Israel, symbolizing the removal of past shame and the beginning of a new chapter in God’s promises.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass, when Joshua was by Jericho, that he lifted up his eyes and looked, and, behold, there stood a man over against him with his sword drawn in his hand: and Joshua went unto him, and said unto him, Art thou for us, or for our adversaries?
keyVerses.significance: Joshua’s encounter reveals God’s direct involvement in the battle, assuring believers of divine leadership and protection.

keyVerses.text: And the captain of the LORD'S host said unto Joshua, Loose thy shoe from off thy foot; for the place whereon thou standest is holy. And Joshua did so.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the holiness of God’s presence and the need for reverence when approaching Him.
